body_changes: Increase in hCG, estrogen, and progesterone affecting metabolism and mood regulation.
Breast tissue grows and becomes more sensitive as milk ducts begin developing.
Uterus enlarges slightly, though not always visible externally.
Blood volume begins increasing, potentially causing lightheadedness.
Energy levels fluctuate significantly due to metabolic rebalancing.
common_symptoms: Nausea and vomiting (most common in mornings).
Heightened sensitivity to smell influencing food preferences.
Frequent urination triggered by hormonal influence, not uterus size yet.
Frequent fatigue and increased need for sleep.
Mild cramping and abdominal heaviness as uterus begins expanding.
baby_development_summary: Organogenesis begins. Neural tube forms early. Baby’s heart starts beating around week 6. Facial features, limb buds, and early skeletal structures appear.

development_milestones.details: Cell division, implantation, and placenta formation begin.
Neural tube closure; heartbeat detectable; basic organ systems begin forming.
Fingers, toes, eyelids form; fetus develops basic motor reflexes.

body_changes: Visible baby bump develops as uterus expands into abdominal cavity.
Skin pigmentation changes such as linea nigra may appear.
Energy levels generally improve compared to the first trimester.
Increased blood volume may cause nasal congestion or mild swelling.
Appetite typically increases as nausea subsides.
common_symptoms: Fetal movement (quickening) is typically first noticeable.
Heartburn due to relaxation of the esophageal sphincter.
Leg cramps commonly occur during sleep.
Round ligament pain forms from abdominal stretching.
Steady weight gain becomes more consistent.
baby_development_summary: Fetus grows rapidly in size and weight. Skeletal system strengthens. Sensory organs develop; baby can hear sounds. Movements become coordinated.

development_milestones.details: Facial expressions and coordinated movement begin.
Mother can feel fetal movement; lanugo forms.
Lung development increases, and fetus practices breathing movements.

body_changes: Uterus rises and presses against diaphragm causing shortness of breath.
Braxton Hicks contractions increase in frequency and intensity.
Lower back pain increases due to posture and weight distribution.
Swelling in ankles and feet becomes more noticeable.
Baby drops lower into pelvis preparing for birth.
common_symptoms: Difficulty sleeping due to physical discomfort.
Increased fatigue returning as energy demands peak.
Greater pelvic pressure particularly near labor.
Contractions may become more rhythmic as labor approaches.
baby_development_summary: Baby achieves final organ maturation, especially lungs and brain. Fat accumulates, improving temperature regulation. Baby moves into birth position.

development_milestones.details: Brain growth accelerates; sleep-wake cycles develop.
Bones harden; lungs reach near-maturity; baby positions head-down.
Baby reaches full term; body fat stabilizes; organ systems complete.
